results.title_for_label: Pepper’s ghost effect, triangles, cyan and red
results.description:
Pepper’s ghost effect, triangles, cyan and red gives new life to the Victorian-era invention made popular by John Henry Pepper. Pepper’s ghost was an early special effect that projected ghosts onto theatre stages through light and reflection.

“Pepper’s ghost has typically been used in theatre, film and amusement park rides. This simple effect uses an angled pane of glass to create the illusion of a ghost-like image within another scene, exploiting the optical properties of glass as both a reflector and transmitter of light.

In my work I wanted to replicate this effect using simple abstract forms and flat fields of colour to draw attention to this merging of the two light images, while also laying bare the apparatus used to create the illusion.” – Taree Mackenzie

results.title: Peoples of the Skeena
results.creator_credit: James Beveridge and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The Getikshan and Tsimshian Indians of northern British Columbia live in two worlds. Against the mountains and forests tower the ancient totem poles; the old graveyards reveal past history; on the reserves the traditional crafts are still practised. But in the school games, in the wedding complete with white veil and white rice, and in the sawmill we see how other ways are being adopted. As climax, the film shows the action-packed rodeo at Kispiox.

results.title: People on Sunday
results.creator_credit: Edgar G. Ulmer, Robert Siodmak and Filmstudio
results.brief_description: This pioneering low-budget film made at the very end of the silent era, was an avant-garde blend of feature and documentary. Its lyrical recording of the streetlife of everyday Berlin owes something to the cycle of ‘city symphony’ films popular in the mid-Twenties. Onto this documentary background is grafted a simple narrative focusing on the interactions between five young Berliners—all played by non-professional actors—who spend a typical Sunday together in and around Berlin. The film launched the careers of all six principal filmmakers involved, and had a huge influence on subsequent film movements including the French New Wave, Italian Neorealist and British Free Cinema movements. This restored version contains important scenes previously missing and features a new score by Elena Kats-Chernin. Written by Billie Wilder, Curt Sidomak and Robert Sidomak. Photography, Eugen Schufftan and Fred Zinnemann. Based on an original story by Curt Siodmak.

results.title: Distant voices, still lives
results.creator_credit: Terence Davies, Jennifer Howarth, Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen, Channel Four and British Film Institute
results.brief_description: This is the first feature film of Liverpudlian Terence Davies, obviously autobiographical, dealing with a family named Davies and their lives during the 1940s and 1950s. The film is divided into two parts: “Distant voices” (45 mins) centers on the wedding of Eileen, eldest of the three Davies children, and the funeral of her father, events which spark memories of the past, including the frightening war years when the city was bombed frequently. “Still lives” (39 mins), actually filmed two years after the first part, with the same actors but with a substantially different crew. It’s a seamless continuation of the recollections of their domineering and irrational father, played against music and radio programmes of the period to create an evocative and moving picture of family life in the 1940s.

results.title: Dispute
results.creator_credit: Fred Moore, Leon Clore and Basic Films
results.brief_description: A study of a typical industrial dispute and the real reason behind it. A personal incident between an operative and a foreman grows, until the whole factory is brought to a stand-still. Concentrates in turn on the operative, the foreman, the shop steward and the factory manager, showing how each of them came to take the attitude he did and how each felt he had no alternative and was unable to withdraw.

results.title: Disney Masterclass with Roy Conli and Glen Keane
results.brief_description:
Disney Animator Glen Keane and Producer Roy Conli presented a special Masterclass sharing their behind-the-scenes insights and love of the animation process.
Glen Keane has been with the Walt Disney Studios for over 25 years and is best known for his character animations for feature films such as ‘The Little Mermaid’, ‘Aladdin’, ‘Beauty and the Beast’, ‘Tarzan’, and ‘Tangled’. He reflects on the inspirations for some of his characters and expressing yourself through drawing.
Roy Conli is the producer of the Disney feature animated film, ‘Tangled’, based on the story of Rapunzel. He explains the role of the producer and the line between creating a safe and fertile environment for artists and getting a film made on time and within budget.

results.title: Peppimenarti
results.creator_credit: Ron Iddon, Film Australia and Leopardwood
results.brief_description: Peppimenarti is a cattle station in the Northern Territory near the Daly River, owned by First Nations people. Beginning by rounding up descendants of cattle who had strayed from other stations, the station has turned to a successful business enterprise with $1m turnover p.a. First Nations law takes precedence over European law, and all able-bodied men on the station must work, with none allowed to go on the dole. Peppimenarti stands as a shining example of the Outstation Movement, and has successfully combined western business sense with local customs.

results.title: Pepi, Luci, Bom & the other girls
results.creator_credit: Pedro Almodovar, Ester Rambal, Pastora Delgado, Pepon Coromina, Figaro Films and Pepon Corominas
results.brief_description: An earlier Almodovar effort which brings to mind some of the more outrageous moments from the films of American director John Waters. Pepi, Luci and Bom’s out-to-offend plot has Pepi (Almodovar regular Carmen Maura), exact revenge on the policeman (Felix Rotaeta) who raped her by having him beaten up by her punk rock pals. When that plan backfires she hatches an even more outlandish plot which involves introducing the policeman’s mousy wife Luci (Eva Siva), to the world of sadomasochism and ‘water sports’, via her friend Bom (Olvido Gara). Of course Pepi never counted on Luci liking it so much! Unfortunately this video version is a slightly modified one from the cinema release (one of the film’s funniest moments where Bom casually urinates in Luci’s face is cut down), but Almodovar’s provocative and endearingly tasteless humour (an ad for women’s underwear that converts to a vibrator comes to mind!), still shines through.
